Installation View, Lorem, ispsum: Website Title © artists retain copyright

Game Patch - the Son of Scratch

Huy Tran

htran.com

Abstract

In the 90's, electronic games have grown Big. From a slightly suspicious intruder and challenger to mainstream media, like the cinema and broadcast television, the game industry has developed into a full-blown sector of today's commercial media landscape. Their ubiquity is having a powerful effect on the cultural imaginaries of the late 20th century. The game-playing experience is irrevocably linked to an "apparatus", a prefabricated system regulating the relationship(s) between the player and the system. It is essential that the player is made to feel part of a network that is both internal (the ties with the world of the game) and external. The game patch is the latest manifestation of "tactical media", a new way of "talking back to the media". Tactical media has a long history going back to John Heartfield's political photomontages of the 1920's and 30's, to the Situationists and "appropriation art" of the 1970s. Instead, a scratch video was co-opted by the very institutions it sought to undermine. The position of game patch art is not without its contradictions. Unlike scratch video, it has a promising channel of distribution at its disposal, the Internet. Yet, like any form of appropriation art, it will have to deal with issues of copyright and intellectual property.

Keywords:

  • Game patch
  • Multiuser role-playing games
  • Position of game patch art
  • Interactive relationship
  • Industrial game culture
